p: Applying what you learnt in your day-to-day life

Research indicates that a powerful method to manage depression is learning to catch the 'Negative Automatic Thoughts'(NATs) as they pop up, examine them and correct the underlying cognitive errors/distortions, if any.

Here is an example of how you can record your thoughts and feelings in different situations that generate negative emotions and learn to recognize the patterns.

After recording the thoughts you can make an attempt to write down or note the points that either support or do not seem to support these thoughts.

By doing this you will be able to see how certain way of thinking can lead to certain negative emotional states, and how by using an alternate perspective/view, you can change the thoughts to more realistic ones and feel less disturbed. Thus this activity will help you understand the links between thoughts emotions and behaviors as they occur as well as to learn how to modify them.

Check. Set aside some time every evening to use this table for the next one week. Later on, you can generate a new table for a new week.
feedback: Watch the pattern over a week.  Write down at least one  and maximum three questions ( given in the tool box) that you can ask yourself  which would help you to substitute your distressing thoughts with alternatives thoughts:
